questions.text: During muscle contraction, which best describes the role of the dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) and the ryanodine receptor (RyR) in skeletal muscle?

options.label: A
options.text: DHPR inhibits RyR to prevent calcium release.

options.label: B
options.text: DHPR activates RyR to release calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

options.label: C
options.text: RyR reuptakes calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

options.label: D
options.text: DHPR releases calcium directly into the muscle cytoplasm.

questions.correct_answer: B. DHPR activates RyR to release calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

questions.text: Match the changes in the sarcomere during muscle contraction with their corresponding descriptions: 1. A band 2. H band 3. I band 4. M line Descriptions: A. Decreases or disappears during contraction B. Length remains the same during contraction C. Becomes more prominent during contraction D. Decreases in length during contraction
Which statement accurately describes the types of heat generated during muscle contraction and relaxation?

options.label: A
options.text: Resting heat is produced during relaxation; activation heat during contraction.

options.label: B
options.text: Activation heat is produced during relaxation; shortening heat during rest.

options.label: C
options.text: Resting heat is produced at rest; activation, shortening, and relaxation heat during various phases of muscle activity.

options.label: D
options.text: Shortening heat is produced during rest; relaxation heat during contraction.

questions.correct_answer: C. Resting heat is produced at rest; activation, shortening, and relaxation heat during various phases of muscle activity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of shortness of breath and fatigue during physical activity. Upon examination, the physician notes an elevated jugular venous pressure and an S3 heart sound. Echocardiography reveals dilated cardiac chambers with reduced ejection fraction. The physician explains that the heart is failing to pump efficiently, in part due to the length-tension relationship of the cardiac muscle. Which of the following best explains the difference between the length-tension relationship in skeletal muscle and cardiac muscle relevant to this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The operating point for both skeletal and cardiac muscles is at the same point on the tension curve

options.label: B
options.text: Skeletal muscle generates maximal tension at near resting length, while cardiac muscle generates maximal tension at slightly shorter lengths.

options.label: C
options.text: Skeletal muscle maintains tension over a wider range of sarcomere lengths than cardiac muscle.

options.label: D
options.text: Both muscles lose tension rapidly when the sarcomere length is significantly shortened or stretched beyond optimal length.

questions.correct_answer: B. Skeletal muscle generates maximal tension at near resting length, while cardiac muscle generates maximal tension at slightly shorter lengths.

questions.text: Which statement best describes the length-tension relationship in skeletal muscle?

options.label: A
options.text: The maximum tension is generated when the sarcomere length is 1.6 μm.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of cross-bridges and the tension generated decrease when the sarcomere length exceeds 2.2 μm.

options.label: C
options.text: Passive tension contributes to muscle tension even when the sarcomere length is optimal.

options.label: D
options.text: The sarcomere ruptures when the length exceeds 2.2 μm.

questions.correct_answer: B. The number of cross-bridges and the tension generated decrease when the sarcomere length exceeds 2.2 μm.

questions.text: Rigor mortis is a postmortem change resulting in the stiffening of muscles. Which of the following best explains the biochemical basis of rigor mortis in relation to the cross-bridge cycle in skeletal muscle?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased calcium ion concentration in the sarcoplasm leads to continuous muscle contraction.

options.label: B
options.text: Depletion of ATP prevents the detachment of myosin heads from actin filaments.

options.label: C
options.text: Accumulation of lactic acid in muscles causes a permanent contraction.

options.label: D
options.text: Degradation of muscle proteins leads to muscle stiffness.

questions.correct_answer: B. Depletion of ATP prevents the detachment of myosin heads from actin filaments.

questions.text: Arrange the following steps in the correct sequence to describe the molecular mechanism of muscle contraction: Cross-bridge formation between myosin and actin Release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum Binding of calcium ions to troponin C Detachment of the myosin head from actin Hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi, re-cocking the myosin head Power stroke, moving the myosin head from 90 degrees to 45 degrees
questions.explanation:
Sequential events during muscle contraction

Release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum

An action potential triggers the release of calcium ions (Ca²⁺) from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm of the muscle cell.

Binding of calcium ions to troponin C

Calcium ions bind to troponin C on the thin filaments, causing a conformational change in the troponin complex.

Cross-bridge formation between myosin and actin

The conformational change in the troponin complex moves tropomyosin away from the myosin-binding sites on actin, allowing the myosin heads (with ADP and Pi bound) to attach to the exposed binding sites on actin.

Power stroke, moving the myosin head from 90 degrees to 45 degrees

The myosin head pivots from a 90-degree angle to a 45-degree angle, pulling the actin filament toward the center of the sarcomere. ADP and Pi are released during this movement.

Detachment of the myosin head from actin

A new ATP molecule binds to the myosin head, causing it to detach from the actin filament.

Hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi, re-cocking the myosin head

The ATP is hydrolyzed to ADP and Pi, providing energy to re-cock the myosin head back to the 90-degree position, ready for another cycle of contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the regulatory proteins of skeletal muscle is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Tropomyosin prevents actin-myosin attachment in a resting muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: Tropomyosin is a filamentous protein, while troponin is a spherical protein consisting of 3 subunits.

options.label: C
options.text: Troponin C can bind with up to 4 calcium ions at a time, which initiates a conformational change in the troponin complex.

options.label: D
options.text: Troponin I attaches to tropomyosin, anchoring the troponin complex to the actin filament.

questions.correct_answer: D. Troponin I attaches to tropomyosin, anchoring the troponin complex to the actin filament.
questions.explanation:
Regulatory Protein

Function

Tropomyosin
  • Spiral-shaped filamentous protein wrapped around actin filaments. (Option B ruled out)
  • Blocks myosin-binding sites on actin in a resting muscle, preventing muscle contraction. (Option A ruled out)
  • Known as the gatekeeper molecule of muscle contraction.

Troponin T
  • Attached to tropomyosin.
  • Anchors the troponin complex to the actin filament.

Troponin I
  • Acts as the inhibitory subunit of troponin.
  • Helps position tropomyosin over myosin-binding sites on actin, preventing actin-myosin interaction in a resting muscle.

Troponin C
  • Binds with calcium ions, up to 4 ions at a time (Option C)
  • The binding of calcium ions causes a conformational change in the troponin complex, moving tropomyosin away from the myosin-binding sites on actin, allowing muscle contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the sliding filament mechanism of muscle contraction?

options.label: A
options.text: The sarcomere shortens as actin filaments slide over myosin filaments.

options.label: B
options.text: Contraction is triggered by action potential causing the release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum

options.label: C
options.text: The I-band & H-zone shortens and can disappear during full contraction.

options.label: D
options.text: Calcium ions bind to tropomyosin, allowing myosin to attach to actin.

questions.correct_answer: D. Calcium ions bind to tropomyosin, allowing myosin to attach to actin.

questions.text: Match the labeled parts of the sarcomere (A, B, C, D, E) with their correct names. 1. Z-line 2. I-band 3. M-line 4. A-band 5. H-zone

A 25-year-old athlete presents with muscle pain following intense exercise. A muscle biopsy is performed, and microscopic examination reveals the structural organization of muscle tissue. Which of the following correctly matches the muscle components with their descriptions?

options.label: A
options.text: Fascicle - individual muscle cell; Fibre - bundle of myofibrils; Myofibril - contains contractile proteins; Contractile protein - forms entire muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: Fascicle - bundle of muscle fibres; Fibre - single muscle cell; Myofibril - contains sarcomeres; Contractile protein - actin and myosin.

options.label: C
options.text: Fascicle - single muscle cell; Fibre - contains sarcomeres; Myofibril - bundle of fascicles; Contractile protein - forms myofibrils

options.label: D
options.text: Fascicle - bundle of muscle fibres; Fibre - contains sarcomeres; Myofibril - individual muscle cell; Contractile protein - actin and myosin.

questions.correct_answer: B. Fascicle - bundle of muscle fibres; Fibre - single muscle cell; Myofibril - contains sarcomeres; Contractile protein - actin and myosin.

questions.text: Examine the image of a sarcomere below. Which band is indicated by the X ?

options.label: A
options.text: A band

options.label: B
options.text: I band

options.label: C
options.text: Z disc

options.label: D
options.text: H zone

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding nerve-muscle physiology?

options.label: A
options.text: SERCA is a protein of skeletal muscle encoded by gene ATP2A1

options.label: B
options.text: Secondary active transport mechanism involving the NCX protein seen in skeletal muscle.

options.label: C
options.text: Calsequestrin protein is present only in smooth muscle

options.label: D
options.text: Calreticulin protein is present in cardiac muscle

questions.correct_answer: A. SERCA is a protein of skeletal muscle encoded by gene ATP2A1

questions.text: A 25-year-old man undergoing surgery for a fractured tibia experiences a sudden onset of muscle rigidity, a rapid heart rate, and a high fever shortly after receiving general anesthesia. Mutation in which of the following channels is involved in this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: RyR1

options.label: B
options.text: RyR2

options.label: C
options.text: CaV

options.label: D
options.text: NaV

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes a unique characteristic of excitation-contraction coupling in cardiac muscle compared to skeletal muscle?

options.label: A
options.text: T-tubules are absent, and calcium influx solely relies on diffusion through the sarcolemma.

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium-induced calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum is mediated by ryanodine receptors alone.

options.label: C
options.text: Extracellular calcium entry into T-tubules contributes significantly to calcium influx during the plateau phase of the action potential.

options.label: D
options.text: Relaxation of cardiac muscle is primarily initiated by potassium binding to troponin.

questions.correct_answer: C. Extracellular calcium entry into T-tubules contributes significantly to calcium influx during the plateau phase of the action potential.

questions.text: Which of the following events directly results in the exposure of myosin-binding sites on actin filaments during skeletal muscle contraction?

options.label: A
options.text: ATP binding to myosin heads

options.label: B
options.text: Depolarization of T-tubules

options.label: C
options.text: Binding of acetylcholine (ACh) to muscle fiber receptors

options.label: D
options.text: Conformational change in troponin complex

questions.correct_answer: D. Conformational change in troponin complex

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with progressive muscle weakness, difficulty walking, and frequent falls. His symptoms started around the age of 5 and have gradually worsened. Physical examination reveals calf hypertrophy and a positive Gower's sign. Laboratory tests show elevated serum creatine kinase levels. Genetic testing identifies a mutation in the dystrophin gene leading to the complete absence of dystrophin protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

options.label: B
options.text: Becker Muscular Dystrophy

options.label: C
options.text: Emery-Dreifuss Muscular Dystrophy

options.label: D
options.text: Facioscapulohumeral Muscular Dystrophy

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the OPD with complaints of difficulty climbing stairs, running, and lifting objects, and have noticed that his muscle weakness has gradually worsened. A muscle biopsy is performed, and immunohistochemical staining shows an absence of a key protein at the sarcolemma. Which of the following proteins is most likely absent, leading to this clinical presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: Dystrophin

options.label: B
options.text: Myosin

options.label: C
options.text: Actin

options.label: D
options.text: Troponin
